Expectation1: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation1: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story: As a judge, I know the importance of reviewing every case file with care, even for a simple procedural hearing. The file for next week’s case sits on my desk, thick with documents that demand my attention. My clerk reminds me that the preliminary review should be done soon, so I can be prepared for any unexpected issues. Yet, as a Hindu, this week is sacred—my family and I have planned for months to travel to the temple for the festival. It’s not just a tradition; it’s a spiritual necessity, a time to reconnect with my faith and community. The rituals require my full presence, both physically and mentally. As I pack my bags, the weight of the unopened file tugs at my conscience. I feel torn—my duty to the court and my devotion to my faith pulling me in opposite directions. The expectations are clear, but the path forward is anything but.
